misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem requirements (implemented distance formula instead of grade calculator)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a grade-to-letter-grade calculator as specified. This suggests a misunderstanding or misreading of the problem requirements, rather than an issue with syntax or basic Java constructs.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and computes the distance between them using the distance formula.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100, then use conditional statements to determine which range it falls into (A, B, C, D, or F) and print the corresponding letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for coordinates "Enter x1 and y1" and "Enter x2 and y2" instead of a single grade.
Variables x1, y1, x2, y2, dx, dy, and distance are used; there is no grade variable.
The code computes Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy) instead of checking grade ranges with if/else conditions.
Output is "The distance of the two points is ..." rather than "Letter grade: ...".
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between this assignment and a different one involving computing the distance between two points, or not carefully reading the current problem specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the question carefully and restate it in your own words before coding. Identify the required input (a single numeric grade), the required decision logic (checking which range the grade falls into using if/else-if/else), and the required output (a letter grade). Then write a new program that follows this specification.
related_concepts: Problem decomposition (identifying input, processing, and output)
Designing conditional logic based on numeric ranges
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire program is dedicated to calculating the distance between two points, with no references to grades or letter outputs, which clearly conflicts with the given specification for a grade calculator.

evidence.note: Code reads coordinates and computes the distance between two points instead of reading a grade and computing a letter grade.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Assignment Submission
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a complete solution for a different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the required Grade Calculator program for Q3. None of the required criteria for Q3 were met.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes this code fulfills the requirements for Q3, possibly due to submitting the wrong file or misreading the question prompt.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Q3 requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and using conditional statements to determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, F).
symptoms: Code prompts for coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade.
Code calculates Euclidean distance.
Lack of any conditional logic (if/else if/else) required for grade mapping.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student failed to match the submitted code to the required assignment (Q3 Grade Calculator).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please locate and submit the correct code written for the Grade Calculator assignment (Q3). Ensure the program reads one integer grade and outputs a letter grade based on the specified ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is entirely dedicated to a geometry problem (distance calculation) and contains absolutely no logic related to reading a grade or calculating a letter grade.

evidence.note: The inputs requested are coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2), not a single numeric grade.
The core logic calculates distance, confirming the program solves the wrong problem. There is no grade calculation or conditional logic.

misconceptions.name: Completely incorrect problem implementation
misconceptions.description: The student has implemented a solution for a different problem (distance between two points) instead of the grade calculator problem specified in the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a distance calculation problem, not a grade classification problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on specified ranges.
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 coordinates instead of a single grade value
Program calculates and outputs Euclidean distance instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade range checking
No letter grade output matching the rubric requirements
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either misread the problem statement, copied code from a different assignment, or did not follow the assignment requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully re-read the problem statement. The program should: (1) read ONE numeric grade input, (2) use if-else statements to check which range the grade falls into, (3) output the corresponding single letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves an entirely different problem. There is no grade input, no grade range checking, and no letter grade output. The class is even named 'DistanceBetweenPoints' which is unrelated to grade calculation.

evidence.note: The program reads coordinates instead of a single grade value, demonstrating complete misalignment with the assignment.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The program calculates and outputs Euclidean distance instead of a letter grade classification.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Misinterpreting the problem as a distance calculation instead of a grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute the distance between two points rather than a grade-to-letter converter. There is no handling of numeric grades, no conditional logic for grade ranges, and no letter-grade output as specified in the question.
misconceptions.student_belief: I believe the task is to read two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) and compute the distance between them.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task is to read a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 and then, using conditional statements, determine and print the corresponding letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F) based on the specified ranges.
symptoms: Class and prompts refer to distance between points rather than grades (e.g., "Enter x1 and y1").
No variable represents a grade between 0 and 100.
No conditional logic (if/else) to check grade ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.).
Output describes the distance between two points, not a letter grade.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student appears to have confused this question with a different assignment (distance between two points) or reused code from another problem without adapting it to the grade-calculation requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and identify the required input (one grade value), the required processing (checking which numeric range the grade falls into with if/else statements), and the required output (a letter grade). Start from a blank template for this problem instead of reusing code from an unrelated task.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categories using if/else
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (class name, prompts, variables, formula, and output) is consistent with a distance computation problem and entirely unrelated to grades or letter outputs.

evidence.note: The entire program is dedicated to computing the distance between two points; there is no reference to grades, grade ranges, or letter grades as required by the problem.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard for assignment requirements
misconceptions.description: The student submitted a solution for a completely different problem (calculating the distance between two points) instead of the requested Grade Calculator program. This indicates a misunderstanding or misdirection regarding which code to submit.
misconceptions.student_belief: The code provided satisfies the requirements for Q3, which is to implement a grade calculator program.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The submitted code calculates the Euclidean distance between two points. The required program was a grade calculator based on a score, involving conditional logic (if/else if/else) to determine a letter grade.
symptoms: Code addresses a different problem (Distance formula)
Input reading is for two pairs of coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) instead of a single grade (0-100)
Conditional logic for grading (if/else) is entirely absent
misconceptions.root_cause: Mismatched submission file or failure to write the required program code for Q3.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the specific requirements for Q3 (Grade Calculator) and replace this code with a program that reads a single numeric grade and uses if/else statements to assign the appropriate letter grade based on the given ranges (A: 90-100, B: 80-89, etc.).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted file 'DistanceBetweenPoints' performs a distance calculation, which explicitly fails all rubric requirements for the 'Grade Calculator' problem (Q3).

evidence.note: The entire code implements a solution for a distance calculation problem, not the required grade calculator.

evidence.snippet: double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
evidence.note: This arithmetic calculation confirms the code is solving for distance, which is irrelevant to grade calculation logic.

misconceptions.name: Complete Problem Misunderstanding
misconceptions.description: The student has completely misunderstood the assignment requirements and submitted a solution for a different problem entirely (distance between two points rather than a grade calculator).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they should write a program to calculate the distance between two points in a 2D coordinate system.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading a single numeric grade (0-100) and outputting the corresponding letter grade based on specific ranges (A: 90-100, B: 80-89, C: 70-79, D: 60-69, F: <60).
symptoms: Program reads x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single grade
Program outputs distance instead of letter grade
No conditional logic for grade ranges present
Program title and logic relate to coordinate geometry, not grading
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either read the wrong assignment specification or copied code from a different problem without adapting it to the current requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start fresh with the correct assignment. Write code that: (1) uses Scanner to read one integer/double value representing a grade, (2) uses if-else statements to check which range the grade falls into, (3) outputs the corresponding letter grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The submitted code is for an entirely different problem. The class name, variable names, input prompts, logic, and output all clearly indicate the student wrote a distance calculator, not a grade calculator. This is unambiguously the wrong assignment.

evidence.note: The program reads coordinates (x1, y1, x2, y2) rather than a single grade value. The class name itself indicates this is for distance calculations.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = Math.sqrt(dx * dx + dy * dy);
System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The output is the Euclidean distance, not a letter grade. No grade-to-letter mapping logic exists.
